body_text:
This PR will merge many features from https://github.com/animelover1984/youtube-dl
Related: animelover1984/youtube-dl#18
Features added:

[VideoRemuxer] Conditionally remux video
[VideoRemuxer] Add -movflags +faststart when remuxing from mp4
Write playlist data to infojson
[avanto] Use NFLTokenGenerator if possible
[ffmpeg] Print entire stderr in verbose when there is error
[ffmpeg] Handle URL filenames correctly
[ffmpeg] Warn when embedding ass in mp4
[FFmpegMetadata] Embed infojson inside the video
[embedthumbnail] Treat mka like mkv and mov like mp4
[embedthumbnail] Try embedding in mp4 using ffprobe and -disposition
[embedthumbnail] Embed in ogg/opus
[billibilli] Better video extraction
[billibilli] Extract comments
[billibilli] Added BiliBiliSearchIE, BilibiliChannelIE
[youtube] comment extraction

Features not added:

Improvements to niconico - Meeds python 3.5+
[billibilli] Danmaku to subtitles - Licenced under GPL3
Split video by chapters - @femaref has a more updated implementation
rtmp fix - RTMP is outdated anyway. No point in trying to fix it


PS: I haven't tested a lot of this code yet. Will do it before merging
@bbepis Please go though this and confirm whether you are willing to provide all of this code under Unlicence. I would appreciate it if you could also review the code

Description of your pull request and other information
Main part of this PR was pull requested two times by @tsukumijima (ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23824 / blackjack4494/youtube-dlc#55).

niconico (ニコニコ動画), which is not known outside Japan, is the largest video sharing site in Japan.
niconico has begun using HLS to encrypt the distribution of some official videos, such as anime, on March 5, 2019.
As a result, some official videos can no longer be downloaded with the previously used Extractor.
(Examples of videos that can be downloaded as before: https://www.nicovideo.jp/watch/sm32868846
(Example of video that cannot be downloaded due to HLS encryption: https://www.nicovideo.jp/watch/so36189921)
This pull request includes an improvement to allow you to download niconico's encrypted HLS videos.
In niconico, if you do not send "heartbeat" once every 60 seconds, the download session will be closed and you will get a 403 error.
This pull request also includes a change to allow "heartbeat" to be sent once every 60 seconds during the download, and to allow long videos to be downloaded to the end.
We have also made changes so that you can obtain higher quality thumbnails and original titles.
(Sentence may be a bit strange because we use translation)

Additonaly, I write some code for downloading movie from SMILEVIDEO, niconico douga old distribution system. Niconico douga changed its distribution system from SMILEVIDEO to DMC (Dwango Media Cluster) in 2016. But SMILEVIDEO was stored source movies until 2018-06-28, and we can access this movies even now.

Description of your pull request and other information
I saw #34 and noticed nobody had done it yet;
So, I searched this repo for every appearence of "dlc" and determined whether it should be changed. In general, I followed these rules:
youtube-dlc (with a dash) becomes yt-dlp (also with a dash)
youtube_dlc (with an underscore) becomes yt_dlc (also with an underscore)
yt-dlc (with a dash) becomes yt-dlp (also with a dash)
ytdlc becomes ytdlp
I didn't change some instances, like youtube-dlc at https://github.com/pukkandan/yt-dlp/blob/7620cd46c3ac6c265be3730925281f77a801c89c/youtube_dlc/extractor/dropbox.py#L16
where blackjack4494 changed it from https://www.dropbox.com/s/nelirfsxnmcfbfh/youtube-dl%20test%20video%20%27%C3%A4%22BaW_jenozKc.mp4?dl=0, to https://www.dropbox.com/s/nelirfsxnmcfbfh/youtube-dlc%20test%20video%20%27%C3%A4%22BaW_jenozKc.mp4?dl=0, and the link still works.

Description of your pull request and other information
Attempts to fix https://github.com/pukkandan/yt-dlp/issues/82.
YouTube has removed support for the old GET based live chat API, and it's now returning 404 for all videos that I tested.
The new API needs INNERTUBE_CONTEXT and INNERTUBE_API_KEY from ytcfg, so the regex for that is copied from main extractor. I couldn't find a cleaner way to do it.

Description of your pull request and other information
This PR is a copy of ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27859 (as of Feb 2021: in status Open)
However, that PR contains the full commit history (pretty clean and readable), while this one here is simply the squashed version.
This is a new extractor for the video platform Nebula (https://watchnebula.com/), created by the streamer community Standard. Nebula uses the Zype video infrastructure and this extractor is using the url_transparent mode to hand off video extraction to the Zype extractor (which has shown to be super reliable here).
All videos on Nebula require a subscription to access. Multiple authentication methods are supported, with the most convenient probably being .netrc, but a few alternatives (cookie jar, environment variable, token in --videopassword) have been implemented as well.
As there are no known freely available videos, the three test cases only pass when an auth token to a user account with a (paid) subscription is present. This can be specified using the NEBULA_TOKEN environment variable (as I couldn't figure out a way to use --netrc in unit tests).
I have aimed to provide comprehensive documentation of approach and behavior in class and method docstrings.
Initial discussion has occured on issue ytdl-org/youtube-dl#21258. I didn't open the issue, but hijacked it for my implementation.
Afterwards, development discussion has occured over multiple months on PR ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24805. The fork that PR was based on has been destroyed by the DMCA takedown. That's why it had to be reopened as ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27859.

YouTube appears to be abandoning the old 'browse_ajax' API for the new POST front-end API. This is evident with the rise in 404 related errors during playlist downloads. ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28289 ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28327 ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28324
This PR is a hot fix to use this new API when getting the next page using the continuation token. I have not thoroughly tested this so more work may need to be done.

New extractor for wim.tv

New extractor for Pluto TV's on-demand VODs. Originally submitted on Youtube-dl's pull requests by https://github.com/kevinoconnor7.
You can download movies, episodes, complete seasons or the entire tv show.
Examples:
TV show: https://pluto.tv/on-demand/series/adventures-of-sonic-the-hedgehog/
Season: https://pluto.tv/on-demand/series/adventures-of-sonic-the-hedgehog/season/1/
Episode: https://pluto.tv/on-demand/series/adventures-of-sonic-the-hedgehog/season/1/episode/super-special-sonic-search-and-smash-squad-1992-1-1
Movie: https://pluto.tv/on-demand/movies/roman-holiday-1952-1-1

Very much WIP. This is a rewrite of the comments extraction. I have rewrote this in similar fashion to how the Tab Extractor _entries function works. This should also make switching API's easier if YouTube ever deprecates this one in the future.
Fixes:

#121

TODO:

check externalErrorMessage actually exists
investigate 413 errors in more depth
fix protected member accesses for extracting continuations
for the expected_video_comment_count removal of "comments" word, check if that is actually needed anymore

Improvements that can be added:

Better console output for reply pages
Limit amount of comments downloaded (can probably be done in _extract_comments)
Switch sorting modes (continuations for this are in header of continuation_renderer)
Disable/Enable replies
Last but not least:
Needs a lot of testing.

Description of your pull request and other information
Some videos couldn't be downloaded because of Fairplay encryption. Alternate video manifests are available that don't use Fairplay.
Additional thumbnail images were added, often larger than the single 1920x1080 image identified by the previous version of the extractor.
"season_number" and "series" were being added to "title" for some reason. That behavior was removed.
"series" now gets displayed as "NA" rather than "_" when its value is empty.
To do: Add fallbacks.

Description of your pull request and other information
Adds extractor for NFHS Network, a subscription site for high school sporting events. This site has terrible security and all data can be accessed through unauthenticated API endpoints. I purposely left some things commented because I have a couple questions.


Should url be hardcoded in each of the test's info_dict? Unlike most streaming sites today, NFHS Network uses static m3u8 urls with no parameters or variation of any kind.


I'm not sure how to sort the formats, because _sort_formats incorrectly chooses best when given one stream with a lower bitrate and declared codecs and another stream with higher bitrate and no declared codecs. This is why I (temporarily) removed it.




Not all HLS playlists served by NFHS Network are sorted, so some sorting must be implemented.
Example: the playlist served for this event https://www.nfhsnetwork.com/events/wiaa-wi/gam5cb37c4cfc: https://hls.bcast.nfhsnetwork.com/broadcast/bdcb2c62fccc9/vod.m3u8 is not sorted.
This is my first time contributing to yt-dlp, so I hope the code isn't too terrible.

The channel syncid (or "delegated session id") is also available in the ytcfg. This PR adds support to the syncid extraction function to be able to extract it from ytcfg.
In ytcfg:
DATASYNC_ID is the exact same format as datasyncId
DELEGATED_SESSION_ID appears to be the channel syncid itself that we extract only if we are on a secondary account.
Also to note - the comment extractor was already calling this function using ytcfg. Which means it was never extracting the syncid. (Though the comment api ajax endpoint may not require this syncid at this time)

As well as for if the comments API changes to this new one.
This also adds upgrades the mix extractor to use the API.

Initially adapted from ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6144. After submitting this PR, I also added extraction from DASH and Smooth Streaming manifests and converted more extractors. The ComCarCoff extractor has been removed since the original PR was submitted upstream, but I tested the manifest parsers with most of the extractors that I also modified in this one. I have not tested this on any live streams; I doubt any of the downloaders work with those.
Not all extractors have been converted to pick up subtitle tracks from streaming manifests; instead, to facilitate incremental porting and maintain compatibility with upstream extractors, wrappers have been added that discard any subtitle tracks and only return audio and video streams. Those wrappers will report a warning if any subtitle tracks are detected that couldn’t be returned, to ease diagnosis and identification of potential porting targets. More potential sites can be found by searching through the upstream issue tracker: https://github.com/ytdl-org/youtube-dl/issues?q=%22Unknown+MIME+type+application%2Fmp4+in+DASH+manifest%22
This PR should (in some cases partially) resolve or subsume the following:

#73
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6106
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6144
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14630
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14635
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14977
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#15424 (not tested)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#18267 (not tested)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#21438 (duplicate of 27899 later)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#22379 (not tested; and only partially, as only the subtitle part was addressed)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23557
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23609
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23899 (not tested; as there is no dedicated extractor for mubi.com, this is only so far as the generic extractor supports it)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24375
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24517
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24595 (note: DASH-segmented subtitle downloads are unusable, HLS-segmented ones are okay)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24886
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27215 (not tested; partially, as extraction fixes are not included, but those can be cherry-picked without a conflict)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27899 (partially; decryption has not been implemented tested to work)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28132

https://devstreaming-cdn.apple.com/videos/streaming/examples/bipbop_16x9/bipbop_16x9_variant.m3u8
https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.m3u8


DASH:

http://rdmedia.bbc.co.uk/dash/ondemand/elephants_dream/ (TTML)
https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.mpd (TTML)


Smooth Streaming:

https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/Manifest (TTML)




Remaining issues:

 HLS subtitle support

 Assembling on the fly, without keeping temporary files around
 AES support: untested, but should work as long as it works the same way as normal streams
 Correctness of timestamp adjustment against X-TIMESTAMP-MAP
 Cue deduplication (how many can be duplicated between segments, is deduplication even necessary)
 Handling of late header blocks: we leave a warning, might need to revisit this later
 Handling of direct links to subtitle streams: postponed to a future pull request


 DASH subtitle support

 Playability of assembled DASH subtitles: postponed


 Smooth Streaming subtitle support

 Playability and validity of assembled SSTR subtitles: postponed


 Migration of remaining extractors: we keep the compat wrappers, further extractors will be migrated incrementally; no more will be migrated in this pull request
 Language code normalisation: postponed
 Alternative stream URL in the Rooster Teeth extractor

The purpose of this pull request is to fix an issue in the tenplay extractor, where the script would not correctly obtain an authentication token before attempting to download a video, resulting in a 403 error. I've solved this by requiring a username and password to generate the token, and then providing it when downloading the m3u8 playlist.
I've also made some minor adjustments to the metadata that is extracted, as the tenplay API has been updated and the json keys changed. (e.g 'picture' has been changed to imageUrl for show thumbnails).

Description of your pull request and other information
Hi! This is my first pull request, so forgive me if there are any formatting errors or such in the code.
As mentioned in youtube-dl PR #25717, both ffmpeg and AtomicParsley support embedding both JPEG and PNG files. Accordingly, if yt-dlp is given either a JPEG or PNG file, yt-dlp will pass the files along without issue to be embedded.
However, yt-dlp currently only supports converting thumbnails to JPG if they are in another, unsupported format. I believe this is behavior inherited from youtube-dl. This confused me a bit since although both JPG and PNG are allowed to be embedded, you can only convert to JPG. Since ffmpeg supports converting files to PNG (I've tested this on ffmpeg-win-2.2.2), I've opened this pull request to allow thumbnails to be converted to PNG using --convert-thumbnails png.
Since PNG is a lossless format in contrast to JPEG, which is lossy, I've also changed the default behavior to convert thumbnails in unsupported formats to PNG. PNG is supported in both .mp4 files (via ID3) and .mkv files.
Thank you for your time!

This implements a downloader for slideshow-like streams and uses it to download slides from Mediasite presentations and also thumbnail streams found in DASH manifests.
The hardest part was probably picking the format for the downloaded slides. I needed a format that is:

self-contained (in a single file)
easy to generate
can losslessly accommodate stand-alone images in disparate formats in a single file
can be readily opened by widely available software

Given these constraints, my only option was… MHTML. This is admittedly an unorthodox choice for a media format, and it should be noted that basically the only major software that supports it now are Blink-based browsers. Nevertheless, thanks to the HTML stub included in the file, the slideshow in the file can be readily viewed in those. I would have even included an interactive player, if it weren’t for the fact that Chromium doesn’t run scripts in MHTML files, so it would have been a considerable effort to implement something that wouldn’t even be usable; thus, I limited myself to including some basic CSS to make the slideshow passively viewable in a browser. Should the user want to extract the images, they will have no problem finding software libraries to process MIME multipart messages.
This addresses:

ytdl-org/youtube-dl#11185 (comment)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#4540 (comment)
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#4974 (comment)

Description of your pull request and other information
Basic support for saved Youtube videos on the Wayback Machine (web.archive.org)
This uses the https://web.archive.org/web/2oe_/http://wayback-fakeurl.archive.org/yt/<video id> endpoint where the web archive provides the link to the video file, if it exists (or the backend is working).
I've also added some basic code that attempts to extract the format details and/or extension from the video url web archive provides. Though, this won't work in all cases (e.g. old flash videos don't have details in the url).
I have also had to go against convention here with having no title. I have hard-coded "Unknown Video" as the title to pass tests. The original PR had support for this by extracting the <title> element from the archived html page, but that brings mulitple issues (redirect page, saved videos without html page, etc.)
I have (re)implemented basic title extraction, with some checks to help ensure it is reliable. However, there are still cases where the title will fail to be extracted (redirect page, not archived, or YouTube having a weird phase of rewriting title tags). So in those cases we default to the video id for the title.
TODO:

 check the regex (I'm pretty new at regex!)
  investigate returning and improving title extraction

Also related: ytdl-org/youtube-dl#13655

Description of your pull request and other information
This is a complete replacement of SponSkrub. New features:

Proper cut implemented using concat FFmpeg demuxer, mentioned in faissaloo/SponSkrub#32. According to https://sattlers.org/2019/09/30/ffmpeg-split-and-cut-video-segments/, small stutter/frame skipping mentioned in the issue can be fixed by forcing key frames, an option for which is also provided.
Implementation takes videoDuration from SponsorBlock responses into account.
Implementation is compatible with --skip-chapters.
Different chapter merge algorithm, which does not lead to "Chapter end time X before chapter start Y" reported in faissaloo/SponSkrub#27.
SRT, ASS, and VTT subtitles (seems like FFmpeg does not fully support others) are cut along with the video, solving faissaloo/SponSkrub#21.
Fully cross-platform (SponSkrub still doesn't have macOS binaries).
Requires no external dependencies.
Written in Python, not in D, which makes contributing much easier.

Fixes #413
Live chat extraction used to be supported for replays only. This pull request adds support for real time live chat, too. To avoid breaking any existing projects depending on the format of the replay chat files, this pull request adds a container resembing the replay format, parsing unknown information from the available context. A flag isLive is also added so that consumers can do special processing for non-replay live chat files if needed.
You have to use multiple instances if you want to download both video and chat at the same time: #413 (comment)

Description of your pull request and other information
The "--ignore-no-formats-error" parameter does not work as expected when extracting video info using the "--simulate" or "--skip-download" options, with yt-dlp bailing out on undownloadable videos without printing any information. This issue makes extracting information from scheduled livestreams/premieres or membership videos impossible, as no information is returned. This PR allows such information to be extracted and the videos filterable similar to uploads and archived livestreams. Specifically, we continue processing when no formats are found so that json output and other possbile extractions work.
We also add "is_upcoming", "live_starttime", and "live_endtime" to the info dict, as they are useful for livestreams and premieres (especially is_upcoming) and no other equivalent exists.

Rewrite of the funimation extractor to fix #428
Potential issues:

The id of the videos have changed. Since both dub and sub formats are extracted, the experience_id cannot be used as the video id and instead the episode_id is used. This means that all existing archives will break
The information of all languages is always extracted. Maybe there should be an some way for the user to pre-select the language?

Description of your pull request and other information
Recently, it became possible to download Youtube live chat live without having to wait until after a stream has ended. With a different patch, it became possible to download metadata about "upcoming" streams using the --ignore-no-formats-error option. Since live chat is often available before a livestream (or premiere), it is useful to be able to download live chat from the moment the URL comes up.
The support for downloading live chat this early is already there, however an oversight caused the "replay" API endpoint to be chosen by mistake, causing the download to fail. This patch merely uses the metadata provided by Youtube to choose the right endpoint. It works even if a stream is late or rescheduled.
Note that when you try to test the unpatched version, the downloader keeps behind a fragment file with HTML (not JSON) in it, which interferes with the downloader for reasons I do not know.

Description of your pull request and other information
Mostly just a draft at the moment. Likely will not merge until YouTube completely moves over to the new API for comment extraction on web client.
Fixes #438
ISSUES:


YouTube hasn't fully switched over to the new API yet, and still provides the old token. Currently I handle this by manually generating a new API initial token. I also added  handling for the old API JSON structure (as that will still be used if visitorData was linked to the old comment section).


YouTube sometimes ends up providing continuation tokens but no comment data. Mostly happens in popular sorting mode, but I have observed this happening for the odd reply thread. Currently I just break if it detects no continuation data, and stopping if that happens for the parent pages.


This will need some good testing to check any edge cases I may have missed.

Description of your pull request and other information
Disabled login by api since it needs a rework. Instead added the option to use one of these ['token', 'auth', 'oauth', 'bearer', 'authorization'] as a username to let the extractor know the password will be an oauth/access token. You still can add --add-header "Authorization: OAuth <access_token>" as usual. However this patch allows you to use netrc to save your token.
I will try to see how long a token is valid exactly (from experience I used the same token once for at least a week). There is also _soundcloud_session which can be used to retrieve the token you got when you signed in. I assume it got a shorter time span but never glimpsed on it so I will try the one I've saved in a week or so.
This workaround patch is rather for convenience
For simplicity use e.g. chrome devtools -> Application -> Storage -> Cookies
click on soundcloud.com and filter for oauth

This is a port of my pull request for youtube_dl: ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29201
It adds --cookies-from-browser <browser_name> and --cookies-from-browser <browser_name>:<profile_path> options. This is much easier to use than the --cookies option and is also safer because there is no opportunity to mishandle a cookies file.
There are 3 extraction implementations which cover all major browsers: firefox, chromium, safari.

Since the original pull request was aimed at youtube_dl it supports python2 and where possible uses youtube_dl's own cryptographic implementations to avoid a strict dependency on pycryptodome. Bug fix


Related to #486.
This fixes broken RTP extraction, due to obfuscation the website apparently started employing a while ago. Apart from employing URL-encoded base64, the website code contains a handful of false pieces of data that more naïve regex search might capture instead of the real data; I suspect this may be specifically to throw off scrapers like this one. Coming up with a regex that captures the real data instead of the booby traps was somewhat tricky. I worry we may need to start preparing for an obfuscation arms race, and eventually add a full JavaScript parser and evaluator.

Description of your pull request and other information
Currently, age-restricted + non-embeddable videos do not work when trying to download them from the EU, because the clientScreen: EMBED bypass cannot be used for non-embeddable videos. Even with Cookies, users from the EU receive the AGE_VERIFICATION_REQUIRED status. Today I searched for more clientName's. I found the clientName 62, which is used by YouTube Studio (Web). This client requires a user session, but no age verification. Furthermore, non-embeddable videos work.
Example Video from existing Unit Test: https://youtube.com/watch?v=Cr381pDsSsA (Test note: 'Non-bypassable age-gated video')
Without this bypass:
PS E:\repos\yt-dlp\yt_dlp> python __main__.py https://youtube.com/watch?v=Cr381pDsSsA --cookies "C:\Users\David\Downloads\youtube.com_cookies.txt"
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading webpage
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading android player API JSON
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading android agegate player API JSON
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading web agegate player API JSON
ERROR: Playback on other websites has been disabled by the video owner.

With this bypass:
PS E:\repos\yt-dlp\yt_dlp> python __main__.py https://youtube.com/watch?v=Cr381pDsSsA --cookies "C:\Users\David\Downloads\youtube.com_cookies.txt"
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading webpage
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading android player API JSON
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading android agegate player API JSON
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading web agegate player API JSON
[youtube] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading web studio player API JSON
[info] Cr381pDsSsA: Downloading 1 format(s): 22
[download] Destination: Some Girls from Equestria have a Fall Formal Fuck-up [Cr381pDsSsA].mp4
[download]  18.2% of 219.63MiB at 12.23MiB/s ETA 00:14

Account Type: Age Unverified
Location: EU
The position where the bypass was implemented by me might be incorrect. I had some problems to understand the code. Feel free to correct this.

Description of your pull request and other information
This PR adds a search extractor and search URL extractor for niconico.

Derived from #360. Co-authored by: @nihil-admirari
Hey @nihil-admirari
#360 is way too big and the implementation of its features are way too coupled that I was having a hard time reviewing/refactoring it. So I am thinking of splitting it up into smaller chunks which can be merged independently.
There are 3 main parts to that PR:

SponsorBlockPP - Fetch data from the API and writes the data to the infodict. It should be a preprocessor (similar to MetadataParser) so that the data this retrieves will be available in the infojson
RemoveChaptersPP - Removes the requested chapters from the file
Chapter Merger - This takes the sponsorblock data as well as the normal chapters data and merges them together into a single list which can either be added to the metadata or be removed from the file. Having this be a seperate class/module would allow us to first remove the requested chapters and then merge the data without introducing too much coupling between RemoveChapters, SponsorBlock and AddMetadata. These PPs will still need to be aware of SponsorBlockPP's existence, but will not care about its implementation details

This PR adds only (2) RemoveChaptersPP

Description of your pull request and other information
It seems that the refactor done to my code in #658  skips pages. Running the test fails on current master:
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 1
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 2
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 3
[...]
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 8
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 1
[EroProfile:album] ...: Downloading playlist page 27
[info] Writing playlist metadata as JSON to: ...

AssertionError: False is not true : Expected at least 486 in playlist, but got only 193


This seems to happen, because the new code presumes all page links are on page one. However, this is is not the case. Instead, page one contains a couple pages near it, but then "Next" and "Last" buttons.
This PR restores the original behavior: use the links to find the last page number, and then iterate all the way to it by generating the page URLs.
Reading the config file should use the utf-8 encoding so that the file can, for example, contain foreign language text in the --reject-title option text string.

Description of your pull request and other information
I have been experiencing a very rare, intermittent bug using the FFmpegMetadata postprocessor, where the file, after adding metadata, would always be deleted without explanation under certain circumstances. This only seems to occur when the location of the writes are on a network mounted filesystem using Windows ACLs for file permissions.
I believe I've narrowed the cause to the following two occasionally occurring pairs of operations:
os.remove(encodeFilename(filename))
os.rename(encodeFilename(temp_filename), encodeFilename(filename))
os.rename is only guaranteed to replace a file on Unix systems, which is why it is preceded by os.remove. However, the remove call is not guaranteed to be atomic, and thus may (and in my case, always was) executed arbitrarily compared to the immediately following rename call.
The solution is to always use os.replace for these two operations. This is completely platform agnostic, and guaranteed atomic as well.
This function was only introduced in python 3.3, but I would assume this is acceptable since support for previous version is theoretically dropped
While I am a software developer by trade, I have not previously contributed to this project and I am not intimately familiar with all the details of this codebase or python3 standards, so please let me know if this PR is invalid and the issue should be solved some other way or if there's some improvements that can be made to these changes.

Description of your pull request and other information
Some subreddits are quarantined which prevents yt-dlp from fetching the JSON metadata. This PR adds a cookie that fixes this. There isn't any check for if the subreddit is quarantined before adding the cookie but having it present anyways doesn't appear to cause any issues in my testing. Some quarantined subreddits will still fail with this if reddit requires an account with a verified email.
Example link: https://www.reddit.com/r/NoNewNormal/comments/kxc8s7/video_from_2020_spring_this_one_aged_like_fine/

Description of your pull request and other information
Not sure what to call this.
This code was originally from  #682.
This PR adds:

fallback player url extraction when it fails to be extracted from the webpage
don't download js player unnecessarily for clients that don't require it
try extract js player url from any additional client configs
ability to skip the js player usage/download (inc iframe fallback).

This overrides the clients' config setting.
This can be enabled with --extractor-args youtube:player_skip=js
Formats that require signature decryption will be skipped automatically (since no player url)


ability to skip the webpage download

This can be enabled with --extractor-args youtube:player_skip=webpage



KNOWN ISSUES:

authentication for multi-channel accounts and multi-account cookies may not work correctly if the webpage (and any additional client configs) are not downloaded.

TODO:

documentation
player_skip=js or something else?

Adds extractor for mediaklikk.hu, hirado.hu, petofilive.hu and m4sport.hu
This PR is derived from ytdl-org/youtube-dl#25098 by @mrx23dot, which in turn is derived from ytdl-org/youtube-dl#17453 by @tmarki
Upstream request: resolves ytdl-org/youtube-dl#21431

MédiaKlikk is the free VOD video platform of MTVA.
MTVA (Media Services and Support Trust Fund) is Hungary's state-owned national public-service broadcasting organization, and it's the successor of MTV (state television service) and MR (state radio service).

Also related: ytdl-org/youtube-dl#22190, ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28054
I've made a fair few changes from the original PR.
I notice DASH streams are skipped in extraction, however they do exist. But in testing they sometimes work, but sometimes don't.. So I'm keeping it as is for now.
Note: geo-restricted to Hungary for the most part

Description of your pull request and other information
This attempts to record YouTube live from the start. This does not provide general DASH live downloader, but some part of the code could be reused.
TODO

 #1036, merge using ffmpeg after that
 Work better for streams which does not have very early segments, found in some long-lasting live you can find by searching "jazz live"
 do re-extraction every 5 hours, to prevent from being stopped when one manifest reached its time limit
 Fix KeyboardInterrupt on Windows (works on Linux, by @nao20010128nao)
 Do fixup for duplicate moov atom

Test cases
Long-lasting live: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fEvM-OUbaKs
Shorter live: find one here: https://nijisanji.net/ https://schedule.hololive.tv/
Does it work on M3U8 formats? Why do you enable include_live_dash?
YouTube doesn't provide older segments for m3u8 formats. Confirmed on my end, and ytarchive didn't that too.
The README says "These formats don't download properly" for include_live_dash, but enabling it along with download_live_from_start do download properly.
USAGE
After downloading this PR, add --live-from-start to options to enable the feature.
e.g:
./yt-dlp.sh fEvM-OUbaKs --live-from-start
... and add any options you want
You always need this even after this PR is merged.
Edited by @pukkandan

This adds supports for videos on nzherald.co.nz (NZ news site)
Upstream request: resolves ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28267
They use Brightcove so this extractor redirects to that once we extract the relevant player url.
From my testing there are at least two page formats for videos:

video embedded in article
dedicated video page

I notice a few other similar extractors hard code the Brightcove player and account ids. Might be a bit overkill but I've added them as a fallback here and opted to try extract them first
Known issues:

raises unexpected extractor error for articles without a video

Description of your pull request and other information
This PR adds a new extractor for https://bigo.tv. Bigo is a live streaming platform, focused on engagement between broadcasters and viewers. Viewers can chat & send gifts (using real money) to the broadcaster. Users primarily use the applications to watch the stream, but the website is also available.
The extractor uses an internal API which returns JSON. It checks if the user is currently live and provides an appropriate error message if they aren't.
(This is the re-submit of ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29064)

parse relative time text

can now do yt-dlp  --break-on-reject --flat-playlist --skip-download --dateafter now-5months <feed/channel url>

Description of your pull request and other information

Do not use mutable default arguments in Python, unless you have a REALLY good reason to do so.
Why? Because it can lead to all sorts of nasty and horrible bugs, give you headaches and waste everyone's time.
Instead, default to None and assign the mutable value inside the function.

I can't bother to copy-paste the whole thing, so above is the tl;dr; part.
If you wish to discuss this further, there's an issue #1021 for it. Please keep this strictly about the change.

This allows to download 2 or more segmented formats at once. This is not used by any other FDs for now, but is required by #888

patch for testing
diff --git a/mline.py b/mline.py
new file mode 100644
index 000000000..aa17986c5
--- /dev/null
+++ b/mline.py
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+from yt_dlp.minicurses import MultilinePrinter
+
+
+import sys
+import itertools
+import time
+
+from yt_dlp.minicurses import MultilinePrinter
+
+with MultilinePrinter(sys.stdout, 7) as mp:
+    for i in itertools.count():
+        fb = ''
+        if i % 3 == 0:
+            fb += 'Fizz'
+        if i % 5 == 0:
+            fb += 'Buzz'
+        mp.print_at_line(fb, i % 7)
+        time.sleep(0.1)

Modify sanitize_open() to use locked_file(), preventing file corruption when two yt-dlp processes are attempting to write to the same file, where sys.platform != 'win32'.
With this patch, executing a second yt-dlp instance still results in a message: "[download] Resuming download at byte 2159224", however now the the next message is: "ERROR: unable to open for writing: [Errno 11] Resource temporarily unavailable". This fixes the current condition where the two processes would write to the same file, corrupting it. Now the second yt-dlp process moves on to the next required file, so in the case "Downloading 1 format(s): 303+251" if ".f303.webm" is advisory locked by process 1, process 2 will move on to ".f251.webm".
If a .part file is being used (--no-part is not enabled), there is a race condition if the .part file is closed by one process before it is renamed to remove '.part'. In that time window, the other process could modify the .part file before it's renamed. Using --no-part prevents this. It should be possible to lock the .part files.
There is no race condition where process 2 finishes downloading the last needed file (the audio, ".f251.webm" in this example) after skipping the advisory locked video file (".f303.webm") that process 1 is writing to, because process 2 does not attempt to merge the two files together, instead, when process 1 completes it sees the already downloaded audio (*.f251.webm) and merges the two complete files together (usually) into a webm (because it [process 1] encountered no errors).
In the less common 'opposite' case, where process 1 (downloading the video 303) completes while process 2 is still writing the audio 251 file (and therefore has it advisory locked), the 303 process (process 1) throws the message "[download] Resuming download at byte 523264" and then exits with "ERROR: unable to open for writing: [Errno 11] Resource temporarily unavailable" because it is obeying the advisory lock process 2 has on "*.f251.webm". Unfortunately when the 251/audio process (process 2) completes, it does not attempt to merge the now complete video and audio files, since it has no way to know if the 303 file is complete (and it [process 2] already encountered an error trying to write to the 303 video file). To correct this, process 2 could check if another process still holds an advisory lock on the 303 file, and if not, obtain a lock on it and then compare the 303 file stat() with the expected metadata. This corner case is still left to fix. Re-executing a third yt-dlp process to the same target with the completed audio and video files (still) results in the expected merge of the two.
Untested on Windows, locking is not implemented, should be a unchanged if the included function signature modification is correct.
On other platforms there should be no case that results in a corrupt output file.

#970
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29956
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29957
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29969
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29990
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#30010

Very superficially tested to work well on the testcases listed in the extractor file. However, I am not able to test this on URLs for which the recent breakages were reported: the manifest URLs return 403 errors. I suspect this is because of geoblocking and not an error on the extractor’s part, but it still means I cannot vet for the correctness of certain features, like the detection of audio-description streams.
Issues resolved here:

 updating the endpoint
 extracting subtitles
 extraction from the extra DRM-free endpoint
 proper sorting of AD streams (untested)
 storyboard extraction (esp. duration of each spritesheet)

This supersedes #682. (I'm making a new PR to keep things on topic - the other PR is a bit messy due to be experimental).

This PR adds support for falling back to the Innertube API when the webpage fails to download for whatever reason (429, network error, initial data extraction failure, etc.)
It is also possible to manually skip the webpage download by using --extractor-args youtubetab:skip=webpage
Also added a quick fix for the resolve MP to OLAK playlist handling, since that was broken.
At least at the time of writing, yt-dlp should now have a complete* workaround for the common** YouTube HTTP 429 error reported, for both video and tab extraction.
 *except private content accessible only through a secondary or greater account/channel
**common referring to the webpage request getting 429nd only, but the API still works.
resolves #926, resolves ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23638 (and most of the other 429 reports upstream)
Known issues:


When using cookies, the webpage is required to extract the required variables. Without this, the API requests will be for the first channel of the first account.


In the case of the user passing cookies, and the webpage failing to download, the tab extractor will raise an error. This is to stop unwanted behavior in variety of situations (e.g. an automated script to download a secondary channel liked playlist, but the webpage fails and starts downloading the first channel liked playlist).


Currently, the user can skip this check by passing --extractor-args youtubetab:skip=authcheck




channel search does not work (returns 0 results)

I think this is a YouTube a bug. YouTube appears to produce params for itself that it cannot understand.
See #1122 (comment)

Description of your pull request and other information
This PR adds a new extractor for videos from NovaPlay.

Search results now get checked if the video result is a video id or a playlist id.
If its a video, normal behavior.
If a playlist_id got found, the result get changed:

duration shows the video count of a playlist instead of a video time duration.
video_url  returns a playlist format url = 'https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=' + video_id_original + '&list=' + video_playlist_id

This pull request adds %(hostname)s as an available field in the output template. I'm not sure precisely what the difference between url, webpage_url and original_url are but hopefully either %(hostname)s is either populated with a relevant url or not at all if for some reason none of the other fields are populated.
I think hostname is a good field for the template because it's useful to record the site in the filename but %(url)s can be long. Another idea might be to get the name of the extractor in order to obtain the site name (eg youtube rather than www.youtube.com which is longer) but I'm not sure if that would be easy to do. It's also not trivial to remove the TLD from the hostname since some like .co.uk have multiple levels. There is a library for this but it's not worth pulling in a dependency just for this.

Description of your pull request and other information
When downloading multiple formats of the same video, each format gets it's own info['chapters'], but info['sponsor_chapters'] is shared. When first format gets processed, it modifies info['sponsor_chapters'] making it ineligible for the second run. deepcopy preserves sponsor_chapters. + Better assertions.
May be there is a different way to preserve sponsor_chapters akin to what is being used for ordinary chapters, but I'm not aware of it.

Fixes #1300
YouTube has been A/B testing a new layout recently where they show a teaser comment. This was adding a new itemSectionRenderer into the renderers list which yt-dlp was incorrectly picking up as the actual comment section.

I also added support for extracting the message YouTube shows when the comment sections does not exist. Overkill, but why not.

http://www.tv6play.no -> dead
http://www.tv3play.dk -> https://www.viafree.dk/

So all the Baltics (Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania) now go to the tvplayhome extractor. All the Scandinavian (Sweden, Norway, Finland and Denmark) to the Viafree extractor.
The last remaining service in the tvplay extractor requires authentication it seems. So I did not bother checking if that is deprecated as well.

Explanation of your pull request in arbitrary form goes here. Please make sure the description explains the purpose and effect of your pull request and is worded well enough to be understood. Provide as much context and examples as possible.
Fix 1
NRK has changed an endpoint. It's set up to redirect (301), so nothing fails, but there are no guarantees that can be removed. Also fixing the endpoint saves an HTTP request
> curl -i https://psapi.nrk.no/playback/manifest/MSUI38004414

HTTP/2 301
server: nginx
date: Fri, 22 Oct 2021 15:20:16 GMT
content-length: 0
x-varnish: 202009202
vary: Origin, Accept-Encoding
cache-control: public, max-age=3600
location: /playback/manifest/program/MSUI38004414
Fix 2
NRK descriptions sometimes has the char \r which will mess up the output. Removing this char from the description will fix this
This \r (Return Carriage) might be some left-over from an employee just
copying text. It will mess up the description when using
--get-description
Example:
https://tv.nrk.no/serie/petter-kanin/sesong/2/episode/4/avspiller
{ .. 'description': 'Britisk animasjonsserie. Eventyret om Gamle Brun
sin nye vagl.  \rNår Gamle Brun flyttar frå Ugleøya for å finne ein
rolegare vagl, finn Petter, Lily og Benjamin ut at han kanskje flyttar
litt for nær dei!\t\r\r' .. }

Removing this character fixes this problem

Description of your pull request and other information
This pull request adds 2 new capabilities to the TwitchVOD extractor:

extracting chapters
extracting live_chat

Chapters means game change events. The importance is that if the streamer changed to an other game, then the new game's name is seen as a new chapter from that timecode.
Live chat is the historical stream chat, it is saved as a subtitle with the language live_chat.
I also added a new test case that verifies the 2 new capabilities (at once, if that's a problem let me know), and also changed where the live chat JSON url is placed (it was already saved), but not sure if it's worth keeping because it'll be inaccessible in a few weeks.
Related discussion here: #1394

Description of your pull request and other information
This pull request fixes the extractor for iPrima. With the exception of cnn.iprima.cz and autosalon.iprima.cz, all subdomains now use a new scheme that requires users to log in.
The support for autosalon.iprima.cz is dropped as it currently uses neither the old nor the new scheme. cnn.iprima.cz is still supported by the old extractor, which is kept with only minor fixes. It is also renamed to IPrimaCNNIE and only used for the aforementioned subdomain.
The new extractor addresses the need for login. Though it is possible to use cookies instead of manually logging the user in, this is not implemented. The extractor also detects geolocked content.

Description of your pull request and other information
Basically, the problem is that Reddit does not provide all formats when requesting with the base DASH and HLS playlist urls (e.g., https://v.redd.it/33hgok7dfbz71/DASHPlaylist.mpd). To fix this, certain query parameters must be attached to it, which must be obtained from the video page itself. Although this requires an additional request, it is well-justified as now one can download 1080p videos (i.e., highest quality)
I am quite surprised this wasn't fixed earlier, seeing that Reddit is quite a popular platform.
BEFORE:
$ python -m yt_dlp -F https://v.redd.it/33hgok7dfbz71/
[Reddit] 33hgok7dfbz71: Downloading m3u8 information
[Reddit] 33hgok7dfbz71: Downloading MPD manifest

Description of your pull request and other information
The primary purpose of this pull request is to add channel/playlist support to the Nebula extractor:
$ yt-dlp --netrc "https://nebula.app/lindsayellis"
[nebula:collection] Logging in to Nebula with supplied credentials
[nebula:collection] Authorizing to Nebula
[nebula:collection] Retrieving Zype access token
[nebula:collection] lindsayellis: Retrieving channel page 1
[...]
[nebula:collection] lindsayellis: Retrieving channel page 11
[download] Downloading playlist: Lindsay Ellis
[nebula:collection] playlist Lindsay Ellis: Collected 104 videos; downloading 104 of them
[download] Downloading video 1 of 104
[Zype] 617408d3a9f9bc0001f47b3e: Downloading JSON metadata
[...]

However, one thing led to another and this ultimately ended up being a complete rewrite. I think the new extractor is much simpler, cleaner, and easier to read and reason about. The video and channel extractor classes inherit from a common base and I finally learned about the existance of _real_initialize() and therefore I'm using it now. 😉
The rewrite does not use the Zype API anymore, and therefore should also fix the Nebula extractor currently released, which is completely broken (#1690), raising a RegexNotFoundError: Unable to extract API key on every video.

This version works with all supported URLs from sites that work with the MTV Extractor, ie cc.com, nick.com, vh1.com, mtv.com, paramountnetwork.com, southpark.cc.com and tvland.com. This does not work for bet.com and video-clips within nick.com, however it might when they become supported urls within yt-dlp itself.

Description of your pull request and other information
IMPROVEMENTS

Improved metadata extraction

currently best for polymer UI YouTube captures
Title extraction should be fairly stable across almost all YouTube versions
Extract filesize and extension from non-standard archive.org headers

unknown_video extension should no longer occur




Get archived thumbnails using CDX API
Smarter webpage capture downloading

query CDX for only 200 OK response captures
Tries multiple captures until it gets an infodict with title
order: try oldest polymer UI capture, user provided capture date, oldest capture from CDX, oldest capture web archive redirects to, newest capture web archive redirects to


New extractor arg: check_all=captures,thumbnails

thumbnails queries CDX API many more times to thumbnails archived under other youtube image servers.
captures adds all other captures dates returned by CDX API to the capture-try list


supports --ignore-no-formats-error to allow metadata extraction even if video is not archived

ISSUES

For querying captures of a video watch page, CDX API does not provide captures with extra params in the URL

e.g. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AkhihxRKcrs&gl=US&hl=en
probably not much of a problem, still have the fallbacks or date in url given


yt-dlp has no idea how to sort the thumbnails

we really only have filesize to work with


De-duplicating thumbnails does not work if they were archived from different ytimg servers.
filesize not shown when downloading

archive.org doesn't provide content-length header for the video files



TODO

 Fix description extraction for some older versions of YouTube, if possible
 Fix up error handling to ensure everything is non-fatal
 Find and add more tests for edge cases
 Move video file URL request to be first, so we don't have to check for metadata if not needed?

the page from the start and is only inserted after pressing the "play"
button. We need to query /v-api/iframe-hash/ to get hash to pass to
iFramePlayer.php and extract "IDEC" id from a json in the original page.

Description of your pull request and other information
Crackle has a metadata value called UseDRM. Currently yt-dlp interprets that as meaning all formats are DRM protected. It seems to really mean that there is at least one DRM protected format, but there may also be non-DRM formats. Letting the lower level extraction routines process all of the manifests will find the non-DRM formats and include or exclude the DRMed ones based on the 'allow_unplayable_formats' setting.
Updated the test case to something that has an expiration in the distant future.

Description of your pull request and other information
This patch adds support for Glomex videos, both embeddable and on the (demo) site video.glomex.com. Glomex operates a media exchange platform, which powers their video marketplace service, based on revenue sharing. This is used quite a lot in large parts of Europe, primarily by digital news outlets, which embed in their assets video clips provided by various content providers (for example TV channels), tied with advertising.

Add new IEs

GlomexBaseIE: Base IE class
GlomexIE: Extract videos from video.glomex.com (by deferring to glomex:embed)

The integrationId parameter is apparently common across video.glomex.com, but we have to hard-code it as it is very hard to extract otherwise: it is deeply hidden in a script asset (a webpack component, which is typically regularly updated)


GlomexEmbedIE: Extract Glomex videos by matching the player URL


Query the API to extract metadata, detect video formats and get the respective (JWT protected) stream/source URLs
The API query may return one or more videos: the latter case is treated as a playlist

As this is otherwise identically handled, a separate IE was not deemed necessary
However title and description fields are not set for playlist results

They do not exist in the parent object; obtaining them from the first entry is not indicative for the playlist content
As the playlist order is not always stable (this is true at least for related videos playlists), it makes writing test cases impossible




Let GenericIE detect embeds by matching all three integration methods:

HTML: glomex-player tag or data attributes
Javascript: naive parsing of inline scripts for string constants assigned to integration parameters
Iframe: src attribute GlomexEmbedIE._VALID_URL


Let GlomexIE and the former embed detection pass the origin URL to GlomexEmbedIE by smuggling it in the player URL, as this is an expected parameter in API requests
Add test cases for both single videos and two playlist flavors

This patch adds support for video extraction from megatv.com, a popular Greek content provider and (recently re-)established TV network.

Add new IEs

MegaTVComBaseIE: Base IE class
MegaTVComIE: Extract from TV VOD pages and news articles, i.e. all sorts of pages showing videos on megatv.com
MegaTVComEmbedIE: Extract iframe-embeddable megatv.com videos


When video_id is not matched in the URL, namely for news articles, extract it (article_id) from a particular element on the web page
Derive metadata and sources directly from the web page, from data attributes of the player placeholder element and other commonly used elements
Let MegaTVComEmbedIE defer to MegaTVComIE for extraction, as the metadata on the embeddable page are some times slightly different, for the same video

Description of your pull request and other information
JSON-LD extraction improvements

Support top-level @graph expressing implicit default graph

Wrap the control flow block in a function, which is called recursively upon such a structure
Per W3C JSON-LD v1.1 §4.9 (non-normative ref):




When a JSON-LD document's top-level structure is a map that contains no other keys than @graph and optionally @context (properties that are not mapped to an IRI or a keyword are ignored), @graph is  considered to express the otherwise implicit default graph.


Extend TestInfoExtractor.test_search_json_ld_realworld to cover said syntax (structure)

Refactor tests in a list of 3-tuples: test html string, expected dict, keyword args for InfoExtractor._search_json_ld
Add new test case for said syntax (structure)


Tweak description extraction from nodes with type Article or NewsArticle: extract description from articleBody and fall back to description field

Description of your pull request and other information
"Callin" is a site which hosts, essentially, podcasts. It is not handled by the generic extractor.
This PR implements episodes, but not shows, users, or "highlights".
I have assigned the internal episode UUID used by the site as id and episode_id and the URL slug as display_id. However, for uploader_id I have not used the internal user UUID, but rather the nickname (as found in user URLs). Although this is slightly inconsistent, the handle is useful information which nevertheless should not go in uploader or uploader_url (since there are more appropriate choices for both fields). Please let me know if you disagree with this arrangement.
The code works with everything I've tried so far, but Callin is new and has a limited number of items to test on. There are two possible technical issues that concern me:

The site doesn't explicitly number episodes. I have implemented a way of getting episode numbers by checking against the episode list in the show metadata, but I wouldn't be at all surprised if it ended up broken by some underlying pagination or truncation.
The site doesn't label underlying audio formats. I have assumed that all the M3Us are MP3, but is there a better way of doing this?

Thank you!

Description of your pull request and other information
This pull requests adds a new internal operator to output templates: &. This causes the value of the field to be replaced by a given static string.
The purpose of this is to build output templates that are highly flexible, e.g. for handling non-playlist and playlist videos with the same configuration. Suppose you want to prefix the playlist index of a video in front of the filename. Using the following template works fine: %(playlist_index)s - %(title)s.%(ext)s
But it has a flaw: if downloading non-playlist video (i.e. playlist_index is None), the filename is prefixed by NA - ; we don't want that. A first improvement would be to use an empty default string like so:
%(playlist_index|)s - %(title)s.%(ext)s
This at least removes the NA, but still leaves the useless -.
With this pull request, it is possible to create the following template, which removes both the NA and - if playlist_index is None (or more precisely, only adds the - if playlist_index is not None):
%(playlist_index|)s%(playlist_index& - )s%(title)s.%(ext)s
An alternative I have considered is to add an append operator, which appends a given string to the value if the field is not None:
%(playlist_index& - |)s%(title)s.%(ext)s
This makes the output template more readable, but is also less flexible (e.g. prefixes are not possible). By using the "replacement" interpretation we have the highest flexibility in creating custom output templates.
The resulting output template quickly become complex, but they are clearly a power-user feature. The idea is to write an output template once, that covers all use-cases and save it in the config file. This removes the necessity to switch config files (or pass -o parameter by other means) when downloading playlists vs. non-playlist videos.

Update our Chrome version and drop the nearly-obsolete Accept-Charset header that no browser emits any more.
Related: ytdl-org/youtube-dl#30394

It seems that the keyring behaviour of Chromium based browsers on Linux desktop environments which use the Gnome keyring is different to what I originally expected. Using keyring.get_password(service_name, username) does not seem to work and Chromium itself appears to be listing all keys in order to obtain the one it needs (jaraco/keyring#556)
This pull request adds a fallback for the (assumed) Gnome keyring case. I have tested it on the Cinnamon desktop environment. The issue was first encountered here #1073 (comment)
because Chromium has a --password-store=<basic|gnome|kwallet> flag, it might be a good idea to specify which wallet to use (either with a command line option or environment variable?) but that is outside the scope of this pull request.

Description of your pull request and other information
CamHub.cc uses KVS Player hosted inside an iframe.  GenericIE supports KVS Player, but can't find the video content due to the iframe and fails, so there has been no support for this site until now.  This new extractor, CamHubIE, simply extracts the iframe src url, then hands that url off to GenericIE to do the rest.

Added import in extractors.py
Verified code with flake8 and ran test

Description of your pull request and other information
This patch improves the usability of get_elements_by_attribute and all its' calling variants for parsing nested HTML elements and allowing it to also return the matched element rather than only its' content.

Introduce get_first_element_by_tag, which matches the first element with the given tag and returns a tuple with the whole element and its' content

This works with HTMLBreakOnClosingTagParser, which parses nested elements to a stack of tags and stops when it reaches the closing
tag for the first opening tag it encountered


Modify get_elements_by_attribute to only match the opening tag and defer to the former function for finding the closing tag, so as to properly parse nested elements for the same tag; this is otherwise impossible with python (stdlib) RE
Also introduce kwarg return_content, which allows this function and all its' calling functions to either return the tag content (by default) or the matched element and its' content

A small fix for the bug introduced in version 2021.12.25 for the format_bytes function:
>>> from yt_dlp import utils
>>> utils.format_bytes(0)
'0.00iB'
>>> utils.format_bytes(500)
'500.00iB'
This pull request fixes the unit for bytes:
>>> from yt_dlp import utils
>>> utils.format_bytes(0)
'0.00B'
>>> utils.format_bytes(500)
'500.00B'
I used units as defined on Wikipedia's Byte page Multiple-byte units.

(Spritual follow-up to #372.)
Most of these commits remove dead code and compatibility hacks meant for no longer supported Python versions. The SWF interpreter is removed again; it was pretty silly to keep it around in the first place.
The patches are pretty much unrelated to each other, so feel free to cherry-pick them individually as they are pushed on this branch.
Some further cleanups to consider:


_windows_write_string in utils seems to be a workaround for https://bugs.python.org/issue1602, which is apparently fixed in 3.6.  We should be able to get rid of it too. (I’m not sure what write_string itself adds over plain sys.stderr.write either.)


locked_file may be re-written as a @contextlib.contextmanager


uppercase_escape and lowercase_escape: those functions seem as bad an idea as addslashes and stripslashes in PHP. The former doesn’t appear to be used anywhere at all other than in tests; the latter has a number of appearances in extractors, most of which seem pretty redundant, e.g.

  
    
      yt-dlp/yt_dlp/extractor/chaturbate.py
    
    
        Lines 47 to 51
      in
      11aa91a
    
  
  
    

        
          
           data = self._parse_json( 
        

        
          
               self._search_regex( 
        

        
          
                   r'initialRoomDossier\s*=\s*(["\'])(?P<value>(?:(?!\1).)+)\1', 
        

        
          
                   webpage, 'data', default='{}', group='value'), 
        

        
          
               video_id, transform_source=lowercase_escape, fatal=False) 
        
    
  


where the JSON parser is supposed to take case of \uXXXX escapes already.


Split utils into thematically-linked modules. Right now it contains functions for as disparate subtitle conversion, HTML parsing, dictionary traversal, bug workarounds, command line handling… It’s become an unmanageable mess.


Likewise, move out ‘common’ extractor methods from InfoExtractor, which has also become something of a god object anti-pattern. (Say, move manifest parsing into its own modules, one per manifest format.)

Description of your pull request and other information
I'm still getting some file access errors on my laptop, so I extended the logic to cover a few more places. I added try_remove, matching try_rename to avoid bare os.remove calls. To avoid code duplication I turned the retry logic into a decorator that wraps sanitize_open, try_remove and try_rename.
Notes:

try_rename had a custom error message. I couldn't add it to the decorator and I think it would have conflicted with the error handling so it now raises the built in error if it fails.
I added error.EINVAL (error 22) to the list of errors to retry, as I also saw this error on my laptop (I'm pretty sure it's the same problem as the parameter looks fine and it doesn't fail every time).

Description of your pull request and other information
This is an extractor for "WatchESPN" videos, i.e. anything on this page not listed as ESPN+. All applicable videos require TV provider and are probably geolocked to United States. As a consequence, the base ESPN extractor has been updated to not match WatchESPN URLs and its WatchESPN tests have been removed.
This pull request should be fully functional as-is but it could use the following improvements:

Addition of a test to check that ESPN+ videos raise the appropriate error. I tested this on my own but I am not sure how to codify this as a test within yt-dlp.
Additional metadata to return (e.g. description, dates, etc.). Accessing such information requires calls to a different API pointer which I didn't bother to code in.
It would be useful if one of the more veteran yt-dlp devs could check that I am following appropriate style/abstraction guidelines.

There is no specific issue raised for this (except for possibly this one on youtube-dl) but I feel adding this extractor would be immensely useful considering that:

ESPN is a very popular platform with replays available of many major sporting events and other TV shows, for those with access to ESPN through their cable TV provider.
Before about August, such videos could only be downloaded by opening up the video and snooping for the playlist m3u8.
Since August, ESPN has updated their platform so that only dash DRM videos play. Downloading an unprotected video required making modifications to the snooped URL, which had to be done quickly as the authorization expires quickly. Now, with this extractor, unprotected HLS streams are returned by default, saving many steps for anyone wishing to download these videos.

You need a Zattoo premium account to test it. Unfortunately I cannot provide one. If anyone can provide an account to a maintainer to test this PR, let me know. To the maintainers: It should also be possible to create a new account on zattoo.com (with a Swiss IP) and you can get 30 days free premium for free.

Login
Videos from the guide (7 day replay)
Recorded videos
Ondemand videos

Doesn't work:

Ondemand series (haven't tried to add this, maybe this can be done in a follow-up PR)

Description of your pull request and other information
This patch adds support for video extraction from tvopen.gr and affiliated ethnos.gr, a popular Greek TV content provider and news outlet.

Add new IEs

TVOpenGrBaseIE: Base IE class
TVOpenGrWatchIE: Extract videos from TV VOD pages on tvopen.gr and ethnos.gr
TVOpenGrEmbedIE: Extract iframe-embeddable tvopen.gr or ethnos.gr videos


For embeddable and tvopengr:watch videos not on tvopen.gr, redirect to the equivalent page at tvopen.gr/watch/... which includes better metadata

VideoObject JSON-LD
full (rather than truncated) description (extracted from a span[@class='description'] element content)


TVOpenGrWatchIE queries an API endpoint to get the respective stream/source URLs and then detect formats/subtitles
The thumbnail endpoint dynamically scales image per specified width, therefore modify the thumbnail URL to use the maximum width among extracted formats

This patch adds support for ERTFLIX videos and series (optionally filtered by season) and embedded video extraction from ert.gr webtv. ERT (Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation) is the public broadcaster in Greece.

Add new IEs:

ERTFlixBase: Base IE class
ERTFlixCodename: Generic video by codename extractor, it matches virtual `ertflix: URLs
ERTFlix: Extract episodes and series (optionally filtered by season or episode group), it resolves "tiles" and defers to ERTFlixCodename
ERTWebtvEmbed: Extract iframe-embeddable ert.gr webtv videos

Resolve stream and thumbnail URLs from templates hard-coded in the player page
Player page provides almost no metadata, so let the generic extractor override title

Description of your pull request and other information
Add support for extracting videos from tube.tugraz.at, the lecture video site from Graz University of Technology.
Features:

extract videos
extract playlists
extract restricted videos and playlists if login details are provided
attempt fallback formats if metadata cannot be downloaded
formats are assigned human-readable format_ids
"presentation" formats are preferred over "presenter" formats

Reading the original PR (Youtube-DL#29160) might be useful, since the comments to that PR contain some discussion about the detailed design.
The original PR got stalled because of coding style issues, although the maintainer of Youtube-DL refused to elaborate on what exactly was the issue. I tried to follow the coding style guidelines as closely as possible, and I can't really see an issue.
I skimmed the YT-DLP coding style guidelines as well, and it appears nothing has changed compared to Youtube-DL's. If I misread that, and the coding style did change, please mention it so I can fix it.

Description of your pull request and other information
The existing crunchyroll beta support simply parses the page enough to find the non-beta url, then hands off to the non-beta extractor. This no longer functions for premium content for US users, since the non-beta site forcibly redirects to the beta site. See #1911.
This implements direct support for crunchyroll beta through the API, but only when a login cookie is present. Otherwise, it hands off to the non-beta extractor as usual (this is in line with what happens with an actual browser as well).
Notes:

This is literally the first python code I have ever written. It's probably pretty horrible. I've tested that it works, but the way encoding issues are handled in python isn't familiar to me... I pretty much just tried random things until it started behaving as I wanted in that regard, so there might be problems hidden away there.
Probably could do with some better code formatting.
I don't know that my format generation behaves well in sufficiently many circumstances, though it behaves similarly to the non-beta crunchyroll extractor in my testing. It's mostly monkey-see-monkey-do from other extractors, rather than well-thought-out code.
It's rather unfortunate that there's nowhere to put crunchyroll's sequence_number metadata in yt-dlp. This would be awfully handy to have for reasonable filename generation, as some series on the site have non-integral episode numbers. See https://beta.crunchyroll.com/series/GEXH3W8G1/the-faraway-paladin for an example.
No series extractor at the moment, but the authorization structure is no different, so it's just a matter of interpreting the api's json output for api_domain + '/cms/v2' + bucket + '/series/' + series_id with the same query string.
There are quite a few different stream types I'm not looking at here. It's possible that a different group than adaptive_hls is the way to go.

Hardcodes some data that could be retrieved from self._LOGIN_URL if cloudflare wasn't so trigger-happy.
The data does appear to be constant, but I've left the retrieval method in comments so that if they do change, breakages can be easily fixed by anyone who can use a web browser's "view source" feature and knows a little python.
If anyone knows a way to reliably get around this and download the page, that would of course be preferable.
I have not tested this with the non-beta site, as I'm in the US and thus forced to the beta site, but it should work, and since it wasn't working before, it is, at worst, a no-op for those users.

Description of your pull request and other information
This should deal with issue #2519 , including the improvements I proposed. I have tested the changes in a couple of channels containing the problematic video IDs, plus a few livestreams, and everything seems to work as intended. Regarding the video IDs getting truncated in the download log, I must have misremembered it because I could not reproduce anything like that. The download archive seems to work normally.

Fixed _VALID_URL regex (now it looks explicitly for an optional third digit block in the video ID)
Added '__plataform=web' to cloudac queries. Now referers and access token cookies are probably no longer needed, but I do not dare remove the code yet. Just in case.
Added extra metadata: timestamp, duration and thumbnails for VODs, and timestamp (technically stream start time) for live streams.
Added graceful(-ish) failure if a video or channel is not found or if access is restricted, using raise_no_formats. It now returns a brief error message and the error code found in the json, and hides the exception details unless -v is used.

Description of your pull request and other information
This PR fixes the following bugs:

On some Tumblr posts, extraction fails with a 403 Forbidden when trying to download the video iframe. (This was reported as youtube-dl issue 29585.)
Vimeo video is not detected, since it is wrapped in an iframe rather than embedded directly in the page.

It also updates the test cases.
(N.B.: the embedded Instagram video's duration is marked as 0.0. This is obviously incorrect, but it is actually what Instagram reports. Unauthenticated requests from yt-dlp get the sharedData structure and the bad duration; authenticated requests from yt-dlp, and unauthenticated requests from everything else I have tried, get the additionalData structure and no duration. I have given up debugging this due to Instagram's absurdly aggressive rate-limiting.)
Thank you!

Description of your pull request and other information
If you log in too many times in a short time period, Viki will start throwing a 429 Too Many Requests error and prevent logins to that account from any IP for a while (may be even around 30 minutes).
This will prevent that from happening by caching the session token. Viki doesn't seem to provide any info on when it expires, so login is retried if the API throws an invalid token error.

Split init code into multiple functions
Clean up validation code by grouping similar types of options
Expose parse_options to third parties to address usecases like deepjyoti30/ytmdl#185

Drafted because:

 Can the validate_options be further simplified/split?
 Not fully tested

Description of your pull request and other information
Fixing #2524
Added 2 calls to download pages to setup cookies. First call is needed to set GLBEXP and glb_uid cookies. Second call is needed to set locksession
Changed playback video version to 2.
Fixed the JSON format for the new version.
Added a new test case.

The regex was trying to be too smart. Especially the <x(a|b|.+)+> pattern to detect attributes is terrible since it matches every x tag. The inability to use [^>] for script makes it worse and results in huge intermediate matches. Breaking up the regex makes memory use negligible while also giving 50-300x perf on random pages (from my naive profiling)
I have tested iframe and glomex-player. But can't find any example of script/div
@zmousm

Description of your pull request and other information
This adds a new format filter operater that allows to filter video formats by matching the string based format fields against a regex.
Example usage: -f bestvideo*[vcodec~="(he|a)vc|[hx]26[45]"]+bestaudio/best
Alternatively, single quotes can be used to delimit the regex.
This implements my feature request #2681.

Description of your pull request and other information
resolving #2523
I also added another subtitle track that notes when a screen share began or ended
a few issues I encountered in this extractor
the automatic password entering is no longer working, this is due to a new "defense" mechanism set by zoom
it include extra headers in the http request for the video page that are generated by a js file that is also generated based on a seed
example of the js code:
https://hdq-colman-ac.zoom.us/assets/zm_bundle.js?seed=AADx7N1-AQAAsr6kOeqMVkDZFrY_h7kUEdue172Pbg3WR8ywwtLBJedku_Fm&uQHR71Sqnk--z=q
I tried to crack it and got pretty far, but I want to close this feature first
we can bypass this issue by extracting cookies from the browser after entering the passcode ourselves, I use an extention because the --cookies-from-browser didn't work for me for some reason
another issue is that the zoom recording provided as test is no longer usable, it now requires a captcha and form filling to enter
so I removed it, I do not have a public meeting to replace it with
it maybe be usable if the test uses browser cookies after one registers to the zoom call from their browser, but I don't know how the test framework operates
also, I noticed that if I do not state output format and download all formats, they have the same name and so only one of them is downloaded, is that the intended behavior?
