Description of your pull request and other information
This overhaul changes the underlying network request handling in yt-dlp.
The main goal of this was to abstract away all the network code to no longer directly interact with urllib for HTTP requests. This was so we could easily add support for more modern, updated HTTP libraries such as urllib3 to bring persistent connections, while also keeping our no-hard-dependency requirement.
TODO: https://github.com/coletdjnz/yt-dlp-dev/projects/2
Changes
The new HTTP networking interface:

Our own Request/Response/Exception classes that we have full control over.
Introduces RequestHandlers - these send supported HTTP requests and return HTTP responses
Introduces the RequestDirector - this allows us to use multiple RequestHandlers
This allows us to support multiple HTTP client libraries (each contained within a RequestHandler)

Other Improvements:

Fix issues with per request proxies on redirects for urllib
Cleaned up various legacy code
Support for ALL_PROXY env proxy setting (and all:// proxy setting to cover all protocols)
Support for socks5h (with socks5 being treated as socks5h in the ydl layer)

Closes #6325, ytdl-org/youtube-dl#22618, ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28093



Known issues / regressions

Expected: urllib (and requests) handlers check the proxy scheme to see check if it is supported.

urllib does not support https:// proxies, so it will not be able to handle a request with one.
Previously, urllib would erroneously treat https:// proxies as http:// proxies. It is possible some users have wrongly supplied an https:// proxy, so their configurations will break. We never supported https:// proxies and the behavior was undefined, so we should not have to support compat for this.


Expected: if a user has ALL_PROXY set for any other program, yt-dlp will now pick it up.
External extractors/downloaders etc. using urlopen() catching urllib exceptions other than HTTPError. We only provide compat for HTTPError, the others not. We could add compat but I imagine it is unlikely there would be an issue.

Future

Updating external downloaders to use ydl.proxies, clean_proxies and clean_headers
Requests support (#3668)

#1890
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14523
ytdl-org/youtube-dl#13734


RH Preference System (will be needed when adding support for curl-impersonate)
curl-impersonate handler
Websockets handler
Disable redirects for a request
Expose more settings/configuration to user
#1191
#3615
#1817
--

This branch has been force updated. Old commit history can be found in this branch: https://github.com/coletdjnz/yt-dlp-dev/tree/network-overhaul-v2

This PR fixes the following bugs:

Video height is not reported correctly.
Some videos are not extracted. (Newer Tumblr video posts may use a simple <video> element rather than the iframe the extractor currently expects.)

Incorrect video may be extracted instead. (If a post is <video>-based, but the extractor finds an iframe somewhere in the HTML—for example, in a 'related posts' section—it will target that instead, leading to surprising results.)


Login is out of date and no longer works.

In addition, it adds support for the API powering Tumblr's 'dashboard view', which is both the only way to view some posts and a good source of metadata. (Relatively little can be consistently extracted from the page HTML due to the arbitrary structure of Tumblr themes.)
It also updates the test cases.
Among the metadata available from the API is the content of the reblog chain, where applicable; I considered supplying this as comments but have not implemented it.
Thank you!

Description of your pull request and other information
Closes #2930.
Also allows the crunchyroll beta extractors to operate when the display_id is the empty string, as I've observed to happen occasionally when videos don't have all their metadata set yet.
It currently functions at bare minimum, but there are some issues I'd like some feedback on.
The crunchyroll beta api divides the world up into series, which are further subdivided into seasons, which contain a sequence of episodes. Unfortunately, however, seasons don't get their own web urls.
Somewhat unintuitively, different audio formats (subbed, $lang dubbed) are represented as different seasons. The api provides is_subbed and is_dubbed in the list of seasons associated to a series, but as far as I can tell it does NOT provide a way to tell what language a season is dubbed in directly from that list, other than regexp-matching the season name, which isn't a very palatable option.
The current implementation just queries all seasons associated with a series and throws all the episodes together into one big list, which makes a bunch of unnecessary requests, as it's not uncommon to have ~10 different language dubs available.

I would like to implement some kind of reasonably usable method to select only the seasons you want (since most people only want one audio-language version, rather than all of them) and ideally only the episodes you want, without making a rediculous number of unnecessary requests. What should that look like? Keep in mind that episodes are not always whole-numbered, so the item number mechanisms won't always work well.
I would like to save the access token (what self._get_params outputs) rather than regenerate it for each episode, as it requires multiple sequential requests each time, but I'm not familiar enough with yt-dlp's architecture to have a good idea how to do that.
I have not tested it with other locales. The urls for individual episodes may not be generated correctly in those cases.
I would like to have the non-beta extractor detect crunchyroll redirecting to the beta site and switch extractors, rather than plow ahead assuming the page it got was right.

#1066 has a implementation error, io.open() may apply the O_TRUNC flag to the underlying openat() syscall, causing the truncation of a file before an advisory lock is obtained. In the case where some other process already holds an advisory lock, O_TRUNC violates it. In the case where that other process happens to be yt-dlp, this results in a corrupt file, because the file will be truncated as the other process (the one holding the advisory lock) is writing to it.

Description of your pull request and other information
Makes the http downloader much more lenient on what it retries on, to survive any sort of brief network interruption etc. (given enough retries for such).
We are thinking it is better to retry on more even though some may be unrecoverable, vs retrying on few, known and likely to be recoverable errors but missing many other cases.
Resolves #3056, #2071, #3034, #2969 and prob many upstream
Might also help sorting exceptions in #2861 simpler.

This is an extractor for ITProTV. It requires authentication via cookies (due to reCAPTCHA) and most courses are behind a subscription. This extractor supports individual videos (episodes) and playlists (courses.)
The tests for the individual videos pass. Both tests for the playlists fail but the extractor is functional.
For test_ITProTVCourse, it fails with the error yt_dlp.utils.DownloadError: ERROR: "url" field is missing or empty - skipping format, there is an error in extractor; please report this issue on  https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp , filling out the appropriate issue template. Confirm you are on the latest version using  yt-dlp -U likely becuse one of the videos in the playlist does not have a url for the format represented at line 115. When downloading the playlist outside the context of the test, there is the warning WARNING: "url" field is missing or empty - skipping format, there is an error in extractor.
For test_ITProTVCourse_1, it fails with the error
AssertionError: 'beyond-tech' != 'time-management'
- beyond-tech
+ time-management
 : Invalid value for field id, expected 'beyond-tech', got 'time-management'

as on the site when you navigate to a course url it redirects (30x) you to the first episode in the course. In the case of the test, the url redirect to is https://app.itpro.tv/course/beyond-tech/time-management

Description of your pull request and other information
The BiliIntlIE extractor is currently written to download content with a series and episode ID. I believe this is generally used for series that have been licensed from a studio (sometimes described as "OGV" in this market). This is similar to the operating model of, say, Netflix or Crunchyroll.
However, BiliBili also supports user-generated content (UGC). These videos have a slightly different URL structure, and pass slightly different API parameters (aid instead of ep_id/episode_id). This PR updates the extractor to support UGC videos, including:

a regex update
two match_only test cases
a tweak to the data extraction logic to match __INITIAL_STATE__ rather than __INITIAL_DATA__ on UGC video pages
updates to the API calls to support passing either aid or ep_id

I've manually tested that both OGV and UGC videos can be successfully downloaded with these changes. Note for others who may test this code: there seems to be a pre-existing issue with the extractor that causes sporadic 403 errors, at least for some users. As a workaround, you can retry the download.

Description
In a research project (https://github.com/zerodytrash/YouTube-Internal-Clients) I hammered the Innertube API with 8k requests in order to find a new age-gate bypass client. Turns out the client TVHTML5_SIMPLY_EMBEDDED_PLAYER with version 2.0 has no age restrictions in place and it seems to have the same success rate as  clientScreen:EMBED.
Request:
POST /youtubei/v1/player?key=AIzaSyAO_FJ2SlqU8Q4STEHLGCilw_Y9_11qcW8 HTTP/2
Host: www.youtube.com

{
    "context": {
        "client": {
            "clientName": "TVHTML5_SIMPLY_EMBEDDED_PLAYER",
            "clientVersion": "2.0"
        },
        "thirdParty": {
            "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/",
        }
    },
    "videoId": "dqRZDebPIGs",
    "racyCheckOk": true,
    "contentCheckOk": true
}

Not sure if it still makes sense to try the clientScreen:EMBED clients (are they completely broken?)
I added the new bypass beside the existing one.

Description of your pull request and other information
This add support for Trailers on Moviepilot. The whole topic is a little bit complicated:

Trailers aren't self hosted but hosted at Dailymotion (since 2 years or so).
Most movies link to a bunch of trailers, for example see Interstellar.
On the main movie site exactly one "main" trailer is played.

My extractor extracts this "main" trailer as playlist and forwards it to the Dailymotion extractor.
I'm not really sure, if this is a good method. Especially the test cases aren't really expressive because of that.
Moviepilot sometimes changes it's source code. Currently, the video ID of the "main" trailer is only mentioned in a script comment when retrieving the plain website, so I take this. I'm not sure how stable this is but every other method seems to need JS.

Description of your pull request and other information
Fragmented downloads can be speed up by using more threads. This makes the progress bar appear jittery as it is updated by each thread. This PR rewrites the logic, which summarizes the progress of each fragment and allows updates on the eta and speed calculation in separate intervals.

_start_frag_download() is locked while executed by a thread, thus avoiding inconsistent updates of nonlocal variables (ctx, status)
the progress is only updated in fixed intervals of 0.9 seconds
the calculation of speed and eta is done between the current time and about 3 seconds before, this is more accurate than the average over the whole download time - when you resume a download the last fragments can be read from temporary files which increases the speed but does not reflect the download speed from the server
the console title output of HttpQuietDownloader is suppressed as ist messes with the output of FragmentedFD
when Ctrl+C is pressed on concurrent downloads (N>1) emit a warning and shut down the ThreadPoolExecutor gracefully, waiting for pending fragments to finish

additional issue
yt-dlp doesn't detect, if a fragmented file was already fully downloaded. All fragments are downloaded again and appended to the existing file. This can be detected, when
ctx['fragment_index'] == 0 and resume_len > 0
One of the commits deals with it by warning and setting the file mode to wb. As it is not part of the actual problem it can be put into a separate PR.

Description of your pull request and other information
When you enable notifications on a channel, videos will show in the notification menu (the "bell") when videos are uploaded or go live. This extractor adds an option to get these video URLs with just a simple API call. Community posts and video comment replies may show up as notifications, but they should be ignored. It may be possible to extract from those posts/replies, but that was beyond my original goal for this new feature.
Continuations are supported. Since notifications can be practically endless, the extractor keyword has a value argument that specifies the maximum number of pages to fetch (each page has 20 real entries), with a sane default of 1 (i.e. no continuation). I haven't tested to see how far back it goes for fear of throttling, but I can fetch 20 pages (~400 entries) in 4 seconds.
Since this is an unusual part of the API being used, some commonly used methods were ignored; I tried to reuse as much as I could.
The extractor creates a playlist of URLs with just a bit of info added (provided thumbnail, original title, uploader, and video id). The benefit of this extractor is that private videos still show up, and they include the uploader and video title.
Some explanation for excluded fields:
Dates are relative and imprecise (e.g. "1 day ago") and may also be plainly inaccurate. The action in the message text (e.g. "uploaded", "is live") is not accurate (a livestream vod that was unprivated long after the stream ended would show as "uploaded", for example).
The included thumbnail is weird: for livestreams only, the height is set to 0. There is also the issue that without flat-playlist, this thumbnail is removed from the infodict's list of thumbnails entirely.
A few of the methods could potentially be inlined.

Description of your pull request and other information
This one is a bit experimental
This adds support for downloading youtube stories, which are usually only accessible on mobile. However, with some magic we can view and download them on desktop youtube too 😉
Example story: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PNJCjXkrps&pp=8AEB
Example story playlist: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=chHM75fI770&list=RLTDwFCb4jeqaKWnciAYM-ZVHg&index=2&pp=8AEB
(note these example links will probably stop working due to the nature of stories)
By adding player parameter 8AEB, it enables stories to be viewable (I've added this to the links above).
I've currently hardcoded this to the webpage download & player ep requests. It doesn't seem to have an affect on normal videos but some thorough testing is probably required to be sure.
Currently only supports getting stories by channel id
ytstories:RLTDwFCb4jeqaKWnciAYM-ZVHg
ytstories:UCwFCb4jeqaKWnciAYM-ZVHg
(can also use the video id but these can be hard to get)
There is also an issue where the RLTD playlist is an unviewable playlist, but youtube incorrectly still provides a link to the /playlist page. So I've had to override that.
Also credit to Stellarator for helping figure this out 😃

Description of your pull request and other information
#1546
This replaces the old (and broken) vier extractor by the goplay extractor and cleans up the old code. This also includes a bunch of fixes performed by various authors in ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27815.
Next to that this brings in a patch initially contributed (or at least proposed to contribute) in ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27815 to handle authentication (on AWS, for this extractor only). As stated in #1546 (comment) and ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27815 (comment) the original author of that code (who licensed it under GPL-3) is okay with this being used since references to the original code are part of the file.

Closes #3333
Adapted from: ytdl-org/youtube-dl#29590
This adds the following options:
    --certificate CERTFILE           Path to client certificate file in PEM format. May include the private key.
    --certificate-key KEYFILE        Path to private key file for client certificate
    --certificate-key-pass PASSWORD  Password for certificate private key, if encrypted. If not provided and the key file is encrypted, yt-dlp will ask interactively

Description of your pull request and other information
Extract JSON-LD from the NRP webpage if it's available. If the
"format" and "stream" fields in the multimedia dictionary are
empty in the result returned by the NPR API, use the
embedURL from the JSON-LD, if it exists, as a stream url.
Update InfoExtractor._json_ld.traverse_json_ld to look for a
VideoObject in "subjectOf" if the item_type is "NewsArticle".
Update InfoExtractor._json_ld.extract_video_object to extract
"embedUrl" from the VideoObject.
Addresses the issue downloading the Bonobo Tiny Desk Concert (#1934)
